name: Rattlesnake Ledge
description: Located only a short 30 minute drive from downtown Bellevue and less than an hour away from Seattle, the climb up to the Rattlesnake Ledges is a very popular hiking trail in the summer months. Not only does this trail provide great panoramic views from atop Rattlesnake Ridge, but there is also a great park located below. Many people come to enjoy the lake in the warmer months. There are no motorboats or fishing allowed on the lake, making it an ideal destination for kayakers and...

reviews.text:
Was a pretty cool spot, The trail is essentially a "zig-zag" all the way to the top. Had to stop by the lake first before I did the whole trail. The only thing I'd say and its just my own opinion but the view from the Ledge was better than the other two points you can continue to hike to. They aren't that far from eachother so you can see it yourself but I felt I could see a lot from the Ledge alone. Also felt pretty rewarding once you make it to the top.
Got there around 8 and it wasn't busy at
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/rattlesnake-ledge","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Rattlesnake Ledge Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":4},"reviewBody":"Was a pretty cool spot, The trail is essentially a \"zig-zag\" all the way to the top. Had to stop by the lake first before I did the whole trail. The only thing I'd say and its just my own opinion but the view from the Ledge was better than the other two points you can continue to hike to. They aren't that far from eachother so you can see it yourself but I felt I could see a lot from the Ledge alone. Also felt pretty rewarding once you make it to the top.\nGot there around 8 and it wasn't busy at all but once it got around 11 there was more people straggling by. I'd say it depends on the day but 4/5, great time, dog friendly, a lot of parking, and a bunch of bathrooms before you start the trail.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Ryan Winging It","url":"/members/r-amp-f-winging-it-user"}}

reviews.text: The trail was mildly muddy and the area right before the stairs to the main rock outlook was quite icy. We put on micro spikes and it was incredibly helpful along with using our poles. The people going up and down in that section in just tennis shoes looked absolutely miserable. They were just servicing the bathrooms by the lake, so I’m sure they’ll be super clean and have plenty of toilet paper but I’d bring spares just in case. There are no blow downs on the trail. This is always such a great

It was a beautiful hike with a great view point. Dog and kid-friendly. 
Highly recommend hiking shoes, poles and ice cleats. There were multiple patches of ice throughout the trail, but it got especially hard the last couple of meters as I was unaware of the conditions and was just in my sports shoes. The hiking poles I had were a life-saver, especially while hiking down. There were multiple people slipping and falling, so please go prepared!
Great weather for an afternoon hike. A bit muddy and some light rain. Trail was clear and easy to see. Parking was amazing, so empty.
It's all flat road with a gradual ascent.

name: Twin Falls Trail
description:
The Twin Falls Trail is a lovely hike, weaving through lush vegetation, eventually reaching a series of large waterfalls. With its moderate difficulty, and ease of access from I-90, this trail is great for families.

Twin Falls can be accessed via the Twin Falls Trailhead off of Exit 34, or from the east via the Homestead Valley Trailhead (Exit 38). Most people choose the mapped route on this page, the Twin Falls Trailhead.

The route sets out eastward along the South Fork Snoqualmie River....

reviews.text: Extremely beautiful area! Super busy and mostly a family kinda place for looking at the views but the river and the falls are very spectacular and the surrounding areas of mount Washington. Definitely worth doing atleast once if you are from the area! Didint see much wildlife but that is understandable due to the shear amount of people. Overall I recommend as a family or cute date hike, and also maybe just a fun place to stop on the way to any of the beautiful hikes nearby.

One of my favorite trails I’ve done this year! Multiple spots to see the river and the waterfalls are absolutely gorgeous so grand and beautiful. A great scenic hike thats not too long or hard. I brought my dog with me this time and he had a great time, he didn’t have a hard time walking the trail. Right now it is muddy and some spots might be a little slick, wear good waterproof shoes with traction and trekking poles for those who may need it. Overall I highly recommend, they have day passes or

Really pretty. Muddy. If you are unsteady on your feet, hiking poles help as there are slick areas, rocks, and tree roots. Today is Sunday, mostly cloudy, cool, breaks of sun in between and it was BUSY on the trail. Family friendly, dog friendly. There is a bathroom at the trailhead. When driving in, do not trust your GPS. Turn on 159th and keep going. You'll reach the parking area. Overall a beautiful hike, but seems to be busy on the weekends.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/twin-falls-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Twin Falls Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":4},"reviewBody":"Really pretty. Muddy. If you are unsteady on your feet, hiking poles help as there are slick areas, rocks, and tree roots. Today is Sunday, mostly cloudy, cool, breaks of sun in between and it was BUSY on the trail. Family friendly, dog friendly. There is a bathroom at the trailhead. When driving in, do not trust your GPS. Turn on 159th and keep going. You'll reach the parking area. Overall a beautiful hike, but seems to be busy on the weekends. ","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Sarah Dela Cruz","url":"/members/sarah-purdy-13"}}

reviews.text: Little muddy in parts.
Pretty muddy due to the recent rain, but no standing water/large puddles. Not crowded on a rainy Sunday afternoon.

name: Mount Si Trail
description:
The Mount Si Trail is one of the most popular trails in Washington, and for good reason. Less than an hour from Seattle, the summit offers incredible views of the Snoqualmie River Valley and the surrounding area.

There is a very large parking area at the trailhead, but it does fill up on warm weekends. Per usual, it’s best to arrive early. A Discover Pass is required.

The hike is hard enough to be a challenge, but not so difficult that weekend warriors can’t climb it. The trail is almost...

reviews.text: Not my favorite trail close to Seattle, but a great trail if you’re looking for an uphill workout that has a pretty view at the end. The climb is steady, but never too steep to the point where it’s inaccessible. I think a lot of people could do this hike as long as they give themselves time to take breaks. I chose not to do the final scramble since I was solo, and it took me a little over 2 hours to reach the “top” (fairly athletic, but no hiking expert)

Trail is in great condition - didn’t do the haystack but no snow up to the base of it. Left later than planned and not surprised the lot was full at 9:30. Luckily, someone who clearly got an early start was leaving and I was able to get a spot.  More spots available when I left at 1:45. Beautiful views. Personal best on time - 3:36. Got up to the viewpoint in 2:03 and down (turkey trotting the sections that weren’t too rocky) in 1:33

Id say i’m a fit intermediate hiker and today was my first time doing Mount Si- it was definitely a struggle with leg fatigue towards the summit after 3+ miles of constant elev gain, but still totally doable if you have the endurance / stamina. Payoff was incredible since it was a clear sunny day in January. Microspikes not needed and trekking poles were useful on the decent. Took me around 2hr 45min to reach the summit and around 2hr to descend.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/mount-si-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Mount Si Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Id say i’m a fit intermediate hiker and today was my first time doing Mount Si- it was definitely a struggle with leg fatigue towards the summit after 3+ miles of constant elev gain, but still totally doable if you have the endurance / stamina. Payoff was incredible since it was a clear sunny day in January. Microspikes not needed and trekking poles were useful on the decent. Took me around 2hr 45min to reach the summit and around 2hr to descend.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Cameron E. Perpall","url":"/members/cameron-e-perpall"}}

reviews.text: Super dry trail surprisingly. No hints on snow and not even muddy. Pretty crowded even on a Friday but beautiful views from the peak
Trail is in great condition. Not busy on a Friday. Scramble at the end was a little more than I expected but worth it.

name: Little Si Trail
description:
Little Si is the little sister to Mount Si. The trail is easier with less elevation, but the view from the top is just as breathtaking with views of Snoqualmie Valley and Rattlesnake Mountain. The trail is often covered in snow and difficult to trek through much of the year and many hikers suggest this as a summer hike.

The beginning section is the steepest part, so don’t get disheartened! The trail is well-traveled and marked with signs. You will likely see rock climbers along the...

reviews.text: Trails are in great shape and feel doable for pretty much all levels. It’s a fun option for trail running with good flow and smooth sections. One of the best parts of the Mt. Si trail system is how you can customize your route to match your fitness level or what kind of day you’re having. The view at the top of Little Si is worth it — you get a great look at Mt. Si and Haystack. Overall, an easygoing, scenic loop that’s easy to tailor to your needs.

Dry, sunny and cool on a Saturday afternoon in January. Several parking spots available, and while I did pass people on the trail, it wasn’t crowded, even at the top, and everyone was respectful. Trail is clean and well maintained, but I was glad I had downloaded the map beforehand as the trail can very briefly be difficult to identify, specifically towards the end. No snow. My dog loved climbing up the end parts!

Really enjoyed this one,  some periods of elevation gain followed by nice, level trail walking. Free parking is about 3/4 mile away from the trailhead, otherwise the discovery pass lots are small. Bathrooms at the trailhead were nightmare fuel, absolutely disgusting and unusable. Not very busy on a beautiful Saturday morning, saw lots of dogs and families hiking.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/little-si-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Little Si Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Really enjoyed this one,  some periods of elevation gain followed by nice, level trail walking. Free parking is about 3/4 mile away from the trailhead, otherwise the discovery pass lots are small. Bathrooms at the trailhead were nightmare fuel, absolutely disgusting and unusable. Not very busy on a beautiful Saturday morning, saw lots of dogs and families hiking.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Jade Graves","url":"/members/jade-graves"}}

reviews.text: Not too crowded on a Saturday at 11am. No snow, no mud. Nice views from the top although overcast. Interesting boulders and rock faces -- it's fun to stop and watch the climbers. Pleasant greenery with some views on the way up. Enough elevation to get your heart rate up. Overall, a good moderate hike for late fall/early winter.

Wet spots so if running be cautious. Steep parts lead to slow chill smooth parts. 3-4 views in my opinikn. We got here 7 am and started at 8 and there were plenty of people at this time but not too many to be crowded yet the parking lot was full when we left at 11:00am. The bathrooms are ok. One of them is nasty. Be cautious. No hand washing stations. Great hike otherwise. Loved it. 2:41 time round trip. We also stayed to enjoy the views within that time.

name: Mailbox Peak Trail Loop
description:
Mailbox Peak Loop is a challenging hike in the North Bend area that combines the Old Trail with the New Trail created by the Department of Natural Resources.

The Old Trail is very challenging with sharp inclines all the way up through the forest. The trail was easy to follow until about 3000 feet where it gets covered by falling pines and leaves. Luckily the White Diamond Trail markers are well placed and easy to follow. Once the Old Trail meets the New Trail it's pretty straightforward from...

reviews.text:
I went up the old trail and down the new. Hadn’t done the old trail in a while so was pleasantly surprised at how good the trail is starting out very level with few larger rocks. That is until you hit the tree roots about half way up and the trail kicks up a notch. 
Still, it hasn’t rained for 2 weeks, so there was no snow or water or mud on the trail. 
The trail branches out in the upper part and it helps to look for trail markers. 
Very windy at the top, but then there are very few times when

Up the old trail and down the new. Old route was completely dry, but has lots of social trails - got quite hard to find the actual trail as I approached the tree line. Minimal compacted ice/snow from the tree line to the summit, but it’s basically all covered in dirt; spikes not needed. New route was a nice gentle decline, only one small spot about a mile below the junction where some blowdowns/debris made it hard to see the trail. There was frost near the end and some black ice I nearly ate sh!

Mailbox is like an ex. Kicks your ass but you’ll keep coming back. Up the old trail down the new one for the first time. The way up on the old trail is strenuous but the new trail is just an easy walk. It is however incredibly long, I couldn’t imagine doing that new route both ways. Back the old trail, it’s nature’s stair-master. Patches of snow every now and then at the top but it’s close to disappearing. Crowded but enjoyable. Beautiful day today.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/mailbox-peak-trail-loop","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Mailbox Peak Trail Loop","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Mailbox is like an ex. Kicks your ass but you’ll keep coming back. Up the old trail down the new one for the first time. The way up on the old trail is strenuous but the new trail is just an easy walk. It is however incredibly long, I couldn’t imagine doing that new route both ways. Back the old trail, it’s nature’s stair-master. Patches of snow every now and then at the top but it’s close to disappearing. Crowded but enjoyable. Beautiful day today.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Sebastian Fernandez","url":"/members/sebastian-fernandez-79"}}

reviews.text: It’s was completely raining all through and the trail was completely slushy..,but had great fun all through
DO NOT DO IN THE THE RAIN. Super cool views tho the rocks towards the top are epic

name: Dirty Harrys Balcony Via Birdhouse Trail
description: This is a great option for those looking for a quick escape from the city. Just a short drive from Seattle, Dirty Harry's Balcony has incredible views of the valley and nearby mountain peaks. For a relatively short hike compared to other trails in the area, the payoff at the end of this trail is well worth the effort.

reviews.text:
All trails app helped cause there were a few spots I could have easily gone off trail. Pretty rocky and a steady climb. Good fun workout and got the views today. Last time I did this trail it was raining so I didn’t! 

PSA - remember no one wants to hear your music on a trail. We come to the trails to get away. And we don’t like your music. So please don’t have a speaker playing music when you’re out hiking. It’s terrible trail etiquette.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/dirty-harrys-balcony-via-birdhouse-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Dirty Harry's Balcony via Birdhouse Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"All trails app helped cause there were a few spots I could have easily gone off trail. Pretty rocky and a steady climb. Good fun workout and got the views today. Last time I did this trail it was raining so I didn’t! \n\nPSA - remember no one wants to hear your music on a trail. We come to the trails to get away. And we don’t like your music. So please don’t have a speaker playing music when you’re out hiking. It’s terrible trail etiquette.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Dana Ruch","url":"/members/dana-ruch"}}

reviews.text: Gorgeous views today. Love the windy trail through the forest. A couple of rocky spots on the trail but all in great shape.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/dirty-harrys-balcony-via-birdhouse-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Dirty Harry's Balcony via Birdhouse Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Gorgeous views today. Love the windy trail through the forest. A couple of rocky spots on the trail but all in great shape.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Dan Church","url":"/members/dan-church-7"}}

name: Mailbox Peak New Trail  2
description: Mailbox Peak Trail takes you to the summit of Mailbox Peak and offers beautiful panoramic views of the area. This route follows the new trail that was created by the Department of Natural Resources. The view at the top is breathtaking, especially on a clear day, with views of Mount Rainier and the Middle Fork Valley below. To return, take the New Mailbox Peak Trail back down to the parking area. The summit is steep and rocky, so make sure you come prepared with proper equipment.

reviews.text:
Review will be obsolete tomorrow lol
Parking lot was deceptively cold, was down to a t shirt by the switch backs. Was maybe 60-65 or warmer the whole way up. Zero ice and only a few wimpy patches of snow near the summit. Felt like summer. Few people in the parking lot when I started and didn’t see anyone until the rock field. Top got crowded after a while though, parking lot was full when I got back down.

This one was a doosie, the 2nd trail iv hiked. Was it worth it... yes. Did my legs hate me afterwards... yes. We went up the new trail and it was great, long switchbacks good Views good vibes. The talus feild close to the top wasn't as bad as I thought it would be. Got to the peak and put my sticker on the box. It's a goat that say you goat this haha. The way back down was alot rougher tho. We tried to go down the old trail and got lost but somehow ended back up on the new trail and just descend

Got to the trail about 8:30am on NYE. Both the lower and upper lot had only a few spots left when I got there. I felt the trail has a slow and steady in incline (I’d rate it easy/moderate) until the rock field which quickly becomes hard/strenuous. It’s pretty well maintained but there’s several downed trees on the trail and it’s quite muddy. I accidentally went off trail a couple times but found myself back with the app. You’ll need spikes and poles about 4-4.5 miles in. The last 0.5 miles felt

name: Mailbox Peak Old Trail
description: The old Mailbox Peak Trail is a steep trail leading from the Mailbox Peak Trailhead to the summit. It is unforgiving, there are no switchbacks to be found. It is mostly wooded until around the 2-mile mark where things open up and there are views of the surrounding mountains. The upper parking lot is usually closed during the winter months, so plan accordingly and arrive early. Because the old trail can be hard to follow through the rooted sections, it's smart to download the route before you...

reviews.text: We got a late start and made several loops through the parking lot before finally getting a spot. Boot on trail at 10:40am. Took my friend up Mailbox for his first time then solo’d to Dirtybox. A little bit of snow in places, but not too much and we did not need microspikes. Mailbox to Dirtybox is mostly a ridge hike with occasional navigation through some thick brush but not too bad. Some scramble bits mostly class 2 and maybe one class 3 move. The ridge is wide and there is a trail section in
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/mailbox-peak-old-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Mailbox Peak (Old) Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"We got a late start and made several loops through the parking lot before finally getting a spot. Boot on trail at 10:40am. Took my friend up Mailbox for his first time then solo’d to Dirtybox. A little bit of snow in places, but not too much and we did not need microspikes. Mailbox to Dirtybox is mostly a ridge hike with occasional navigation through some thick brush but not too bad. Some scramble bits mostly class 2 and maybe one class 3 move. The ridge is wide and there is a trail section in the forest going up the last approach to the summit. Signed the registers for both peaks. 7.1 miles with 4600 elevation gain. We drank more fluids than anticipated, beautiful day.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Gina Dempsey","url":"/members/gina-dempsey"}}

reviews.text: Very beautiful trail. The lot was overfilled when I got there and made me decide to go old trail besides new, and my goodness this trail is unforgiving at times. Very steep and a constant step master of a hike with so many times needing to anchor myself with my pole to push myself up root steps. The view today was phenomenal, and I couldn't be happier with amazing views of Rainier and baker. I used micro spikes coming down since there is still snow on the final push to the mailbox, but it is not
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/mailbox-peak-old-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Mailbox Peak (Old) Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":4},"reviewBody":"Very beautiful trail. The lot was overfilled when I got there and made me decide to go old trail besides new, and my goodness this trail is unforgiving at times. Very steep and a constant step master of a hike with so many times needing to anchor myself with my pole to push myself up root steps. The view today was phenomenal, and I couldn't be happier with amazing views of Rainier and baker. I used micro spikes coming down since there is still snow on the final push to the mailbox, but it is not needed. The decent was faster but equally brutal on my quads and I'm so happy I had poles. Overall an iconic cascade hike and great conditions due to the unusual warm and clear weather. Absolutely no wind on top, and it was very peaceful.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Emilia vitigo","url":"/members/emilia-vitigo"}}

reviews.text:
Hiked up and down the old trail on 12/27. There were still several spots in the upper parking lot when I got there around mid-day on a Saturday. Bathrooms at the trail were open. 

There were patchy areas of snow on the trail starting around 1600 feet. I put microspikes on at 2000 feet. Consistent packed snow on the trail around 2500 feet. 2-3 inches of snow on trail after the talus field. Ran into several people carrying snowshoes but definitely not needed today. 

Pretty clear day so we had gr
Little snow towards the top

Zero snow on the trail today, and oddly balmy temps with the heat wave today. By the time I drove home at noon my car was showing 65F. I’ve never seen the trail without snow in February like this, and although it was gorgeous and warm… it felt odd and unsettling. Super blustery up at the peak today, but the air was warm. Upper lot was nearly full by the time I got back to my car at 11:45am.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/mailbox-peak-old-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Mailbox Peak (Old) Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Zero snow on the trail today, and oddly balmy temps with the heat wave today. By the time I drove home at noon my car was showing 65F. I’ve never seen the trail without snow in February like this, and although it was gorgeous and warm… it felt odd and unsettling. Super blustery up at the peak today, but the air was warm. Upper lot was nearly full by the time I got back to my car at 11:45am. ","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Veronica Tanner","url":"/members/veronica-tanner"}}

name: Teneriffe Falls
description: This is a steep and challenging trail to a beautiful waterfall. The trail is very steep and rocky towards the end, sturdy footwear and trekking poles are recommended. The best time to visit the falls is during the spring or after heavy rain when the falls are flowing the strongest. Snow and ice is common on the trail in the winter.

reviews.text: This was a super fun hike today. It took me just over 3 hours. Don’t underestimate those final switchbacks. A couple of exposed areas but not for very long. The rocks are loose in spots but I never felt unsafe. I didn’t use hiking poles but consider them for sure. The falls were perfect and full, I caught them with the sunlight shining in and there was a rainbow. I crossed the falls to relax and take photos. No Bigfoots.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/teneriffe-falls","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Teneriffe Falls Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"This was a super fun hike today. It took me just over 3 hours. Don’t underestimate those final switchbacks. A couple of exposed areas but not for very long. The rocks are loose in spots but I never felt unsafe. I didn’t use hiking poles but consider them for sure. The falls were perfect and full, I caught them with the sunlight shining in and there was a rainbow. I crossed the falls to relax and take photos. No Bigfoots.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Kerrin Doyle","url":"/members/kerrin-doyle"}}

reviews.text: Nice trail, parking at 10 am on a Saturday was easy, while mt si and little so lots seemed full.  Trail was pretty busy, but not crowded.  The conditions were great, clear trail , no snow.  There are some rocky parts at the end but they aren't really steep or challenging like haystack, but they definitely look like they want to chew up knees and ankles.  There are a few spots the trail forks and makes unmarked turns .. keep an eye out for markings from good samaratans. All in all good hike, nice

Such a beautiful hike through the woods to huge huge waterfall thats absolutely stunning! The first couple miles is not too rocky or bad but it does get really rocky getting closer to the waterfall so wear shoes with good traction or use trekking poles! Bathrooms are available at the beginning of the trail and the trails are well maintained and easy to follow. I had service up there so I was able to keep track of the trail. I wouldn’t recommend bringing a dog unless they are good with rocky/some
Nice trial overall. Views at the top were mid. Last mile before the waterfall is a rock scramble- not my favorite.

Gorgous hike that makes you earn it!

Parking lot was maybe half full at 9:30 this morning. Trailhead bathrooms were well maintained. Had toilet paper but no hand sanitizer.

The turn from the even grade part to the switch backs is easy to miss. Thankfully some logs were put across the trail. 

Falls were stunning. Saw plenty of people but never felt crowded.

name: Mount Washington
description: The best route off the interstate is to take exit 38 to reach the trailhead. The trail climbs through the forest and passes a steep rocky outcropping about a half mile from the trailhead. This spot is popular with rock climbers and you may notice climbing hardware hanging from the cliff. As you ascend you are rewarded with some views, the summit has a perfect view of Mt. Rainier.

reviews.text: I don’t know why AllTrails says this is closed, but it is definitely not. What an awesome day for a hike. Easily found a parking spot but there is overflow parking not far away. I’m shocked at how little snow is on the trail, there’s basically none until 3 miles in, then it’s on and off packed down snow. Bring microspikes if you have them, but if you don’t you’ll get by with a little slipping. Wonderful view of Rainier soaking up the sun sitting on a snow free rock. This is a great workout that

01/09/2026: Giving the trail a four star as it felt like an obstacle course with so many trees down and snow constantly falling from the branches, but wow, totally worth it! Snowshoes were needed about 3 miles in, shortly after the wooden fence. That’s where I caught up to a group breaking trail, which helped a ton.

As of today, there’s a solid track in, but still plenty of deep snow, the base path is set though. And the views up top? Stunning. My second time at the summit and once again got lu

Didn't really have enough time for a hike today so I got a late start and descended by headlamp. Road is fine, bathroom is open. Snow on the trail is well traveled and packed. Didn't use spikes for gators. A few blowdowns to navigate, but nothing too ugly. I found the Rocky section to be more slippery than the snow. Sign says Park is closed at dusk; however, the gate was still open long after dark.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/mount-washington","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Mount Washington Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":4},"reviewBody":"Didn't really have enough time for a hike today so I got a late start and descended by headlamp. Road is fine, bathroom is open. Snow on the trail is well traveled and packed. Didn't use spikes for gators. A few blowdowns to navigate, but nothing too ugly. I found the Rocky section to be more slippery than the snow. Sign says Park is closed at dusk; however, the gate was still open long after dark.\n","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Michelle Lazarov ","url":"/members/michelle-lazarov"}}

reviews.text:
The first 1.5 miles are very rocky, so you need to watch your footing. Most of the hike is shaded and doesn’t offer many views, but there are a few spots with great scenery. I also met an amazing man named Andy, who was cutting fallen trees along the trail.

Overall, it’s a beautiful hike, and you’ll enjoy this trail.
Pouring rain today, basically hiked in a muddy creek. Great pacing though, I had a good time despite being soaked. Very rocky.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/mount-washington","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Mount Washington Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Pouring rain today, basically hiked in a muddy creek. Great pacing though, I had a good time despite being soaked. Very rocky.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Aaron Fetterhoff","url":"/members/aaron-fetterhoff"}}

name: John Wayne Pioneer Trail: North Bend to Lake Easton

reviews.text: Well groomed wide trail.  Great for walking, running or biking.
Great trail for exercise, but plenty of room for casual riders. Nice forested trail with some nice views.

The Summit Bike Park provides this opportunity to explore the Palouse to Cascade State Park trail or the old train route. Just, thirty bucks to one way ticket that will a bring you back to your car. Twenty three miles of mostly easy riding !
Went biking along this beautiful trail. So many hiking offshoot trails and tons of waterfalls.

Hyak to Cedar Falls (Rattlesnake Lake) on Palouse to Cascades Trail - perfect day for this outing. Bring warm fear and a good headlight for the tunnel. Warm temps and cool breeze with scenic views frequented our ride.

name: Mount Si and Mount Teneriffe Loop

reviews.text:
Tough climb from Teneriffe falls to the summit. Great route if your looking for a challenge 

Conditions were all things considered decent for December. Little snow up top, windy, and no views. Pack layers as you will cool off after you summit.
Wet, windy and rad

Didn’t see anyone on the kamikaze trail and only a few after that. Kamikaze takes you straight to the top, it’s all downhill after that. 

*After Mt. Teneriffe and Si we took the Talus loop trail back over to Teneriffe falls trail.
Great trail!  Kamikaze is no joke!
Holy elevation. Kamikaze trail killed me. I’ll be doing this again
Beautiful easy hike with waterfall reward at 5 mile mark.
Don’t take the old, lower route.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/middle-fork-snoqualmie-river-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Middle Fork Snoqualmie River Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":3},"reviewBody":"Don’t take the old, lower route.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Jessica Smith","url":"/members/jessica-smith-1152"}}

name: Dirty Harry's Peak via Birdhouse Trail

reviews.text: This hike is a one and done. First strike is you can hear I-90 for at least 75% of the hike and even see it at times. Second strike the trail is rocky and steep. I do not mind a steep hike at all but it was simply unpleasant. I guess because of lack of distractions as you are in a scruffy woods most of the time. If it’s winter and I am forced to do an I-90 hike then Mt Si, Tenneriffe Falls, or Annette Lake are much better options for me.

Excellent conditions. Beyond the intersection of the peak and balcony trails, the peak trail gets a bit overgrown, nothing too bad at all, just noticeable.

Snow begins a couple hundred feet below the summit and it absolutely can be done without spikes, but it’s way simpler just to bring them. 

Also, lots of the trail sits in the shade so the wind can really chill it, especially later in the afternoon. Excellent trail!

In case AllTrails moves this to Dirty Harry's Peak, this review is for Web Mountain via the Dirty Harry's Peak Trail. Far less snow than I would have expected for this time of year. Should've looked at Copernicus before setting out for this. No snow on the DHPT through Web Mtn / Dirty Harry's Peak fork. From the fork, the old road is a creek right now. Had to do a bit of rock hopping and holding thorny plants out of the way. Shortly before the road becomes very overgrown, there's an instant 45°

They called him Dirty Harry cuz he did us dirty with the elevation grade over the last mile! Rocky at times and not the best views. No snow at the top (in February!! 😨). This hike's not one my first choices in the Snoqualmie Pass collection but still worth checking out, especially if you're looking to atone for having skipped leg day. Discovery Pass required at parking lot.
Every step is worth the hike! Great view and great condition
Very nice trail no snow
Pleasant trail and wonderful sights of nature.
Overcrowded
There are some spectacular trees here. Some are infected with deadly fungi, and it will spread if it isn't managed.
Absolutely beautiful views on this trail today! Got here around noon and the parking lot was almost full, but the trail was pretty quiet and not crowded at all!
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/winter-block-via-birdhouse-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Winter Block via Birdhouse Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Absolutely beautiful views on this trail today! Got here around noon and the parking lot was almost full, but the trail was pretty quiet and not crowded at all!","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Tyah Young","url":"/members/tyah-young"}}

reviews.text:
I didn’t get to finish the whole trail but did get half way and it was lovely! 
I wouldn’t say it’s cold but the wind is. I only wore a beanie, shirt and jacket for warmth and i was fine except for my face being cold.
Trail was a little muddy (to be expected) not super icy until the last .5, great views and not super busy!!
Great! I left a hiking stick. Great quality.

Discovery pass is required to park on trailhead. The hike itself was moderately difficult. Different views on the way up. We caught clouds the day we went but thankfully they moved along so we got a glimpse of the mountains across and the freeway below us! All was great

1/25/2026 · Cedar Butte

Parking:
Lots of parking available. The lot was maybe 1/4 full when we arrived. Discover pass needed. 

Trail Traffic:
There was quite a bit of foot traffic today. We saw a handful of groups on our way up, and even more on our descent. 

Trail Conditions:
The trail was in good shape. The first part is pretty flat along Palouse to Cascades trail. Once turning on cedar butte trail we went up, until we hit a fork in the road. We went right for a less steep incline, then wen
reviews.date:
{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/cedar-butte-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Cedar Butte Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":4},"reviewBody":"1/25/2026 · Cedar Butte

Parking:
Lots of parking available. The lot was maybe 1/4 full when we arrived. Discover pass needed. 

Trail Traffic:
There was quite a bit of foot traffic today. We saw a handful of groups on our way up, and even more on our descent. 

Trail Conditions:
The trail was in good shape. The first part is pretty flat along Palouse to Cascades trail. Once turning on cedar butte trail we went up, until we hit a fork in the road. We went right for a less steep incline, then went down the steeper side, making a bit of a loop at the top portion. 

Trail Highlights:
Beautiful trees and moss, sunshine in the forest, some views from the top. 

Our Stats:
4.4 miles | 948 feet elevation gain

**note: you can smell the bathrooms from the parking lot, wouldn’t recommend**","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Morgan @the_fawn_trail","url":"/members/morgan-fitzpatrick"}}

reviews.text: Was a sunny day with a bit of cloud cover. Views are hiding more towards the summit. A bit muddy and overgrown but other than that it was a fabulous hike! Some bugs mainly at the summit and were small flies that like moisture I think! Not a lot of folks on this trail and parking was easy around midday. You’ll need a discover pass to park here or need to pay the fee. I’d definitely hike here again!

Decided to do this trail as rattlesnake ledge had WAYYY too many people!! I am sooo glad I chose this route instead. I started about 1pm and passed 4 groups all within the first 5 mins heading down and then no one the whole time. Yes it’s a bit overgrown, but so magical! Once you turn off the gravel bike path it was like another dimension. At a summit of 1800ft the views are incredible on a clear day! Mountains as far as you can see! I attempted to add Christmas lake on the way back- which was a
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/cedar-butte-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Cedar Butte Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":4},"reviewBody":"Decided to do this trail as rattlesnake ledge had WAYYY too many people!! I am sooo glad I chose this route instead. I started about 1pm and passed 4 groups all within the first 5 mins heading down and then no one the whole time. Yes it’s a bit overgrown, but so magical! Once you turn off the gravel bike path it was like another dimension. At a summit of 1800ft the views are incredible on a clear day! Mountains as far as you can see! I attempted to add Christmas lake on the way back- which was a total fail. Now that trail is super overgrown and I was bushwhacking like crazy. So don’t go that way lol","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Sydney Stoewer","url":"/members/sydney-stoewer"}}

reviews.text: Trail is muddy in patches and has a few blowdowns, but nothing that isn't easily avoidable. Much less crowded than nearby Rattlesnake, and you can tell by the overgrowth. North-facing views are limited because of trees but still very nice!
Great trail. Two trees down but easy to climb over. Trail around Christmas lake is muddy.

name: Mount Teneriffe via Mount Teneriffe Trailhead

reviews.text: Fun! Very beautiful and great conditions. The kamikaze trail was definitely brutal though, and a bit scary at times. There was a point where you mix hike/climb up a section and it is a quite a bit exposed and very steep i mean it was essentially a small scramble to get up. It was very very steep and it does not let up till the end. But it is definitely doable and I recommend this loop if you are up for it! Absolutely stunning views on the peak. I recommend spikes since the snow is still there an

Another beautiful day on the trail. Arrived at the Mt. Teneriffe TH parking lot around 8am and surprisingly the parking lot was wide open on a Sunday. Took the kamikaze trail up and it was in good condition. Pretty easy to follow the trail. After I left the summit of Mt. Teneriffe I headed over towards Dixie peak. The trail is better than I expected and pretty straight forward. I did see a black bear about a 1/4 mile up from the junction off the main trail. It took off pretty quickly. After Dixi
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/mount-teneriffe-via-mount-teneriffe-trailhead","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Mount Teneriffe via Mount Teneriffe Trailhead","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":4},"reviewBody":"Another beautiful day on the trail. Arrived at the Mt. Teneriffe TH parking lot around 8am and surprisingly the parking lot was wide open on a Sunday. Took the kamikaze trail up and it was in good condition. Pretty easy to follow the trail. After I left the summit of Mt. Teneriffe I headed over towards Dixie peak. The trail is better than I expected and pretty straight forward. I did see a black bear about a 1/4 mile up from the junction off the main trail. It took off pretty quickly. After Dixie I moseyed on over to the peak NE of it. Not really. It was more of a bushwhack through mountain huckleberries and pine trees along a ridge. Not sure if the peak is named or not. Saw some bear evidence along the way. Pretty uneventful decent.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Chris S","url":"/members/chris-striber"}}

reviews.text: Was steep at parts and lost trail a couple times but soooooo worth the trip to summit
mostly uphill. not for the weak
Gorgeous day today. There’s snow at the top so hiking boots recommended. I’d say microspikes optional. There’s longer stretches of snow on the normal route than Kamikaze
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/mount-teneriffe-via-mount-teneriffe-trailhead","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Mount Teneriffe via Mount Teneriffe Trailhead","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Gorgeous day today. There’s snow at the top so hiking boots recommended. I’d say microspikes optional. There’s longer stretches of snow on the normal route than Kamikaze","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Alex Liu","url":"/members/alex-liu-115"}}

reviews.text: Great conditions and great views of Rainier, Baker, Glacier Peak and more. There’s some snow near the top with a booter kicked in. It was a bit icy, probably refroze over night, so going down on a couple steeper snowy sections near the top without traction could be a little dicey. There’s an alternative track on climbers left that is beside the main line that’s much easier to descend in much softer snow.

Parking lot mostly empty at 8:30 AM on a rare cloudless January Sunday. Forecasted low 50s but at the peak it almost felt like early summer; even saw a few dudes hiking in shorts and t-shirts. Tame gradual incline up to the waterfall and then the Kamikaze trail starts, which felt even more vertical compared to the old Mailbox trail. Slushy snow for the last half mile until the peak; the snow's pretty kicked in so you can get away with no microspikes but poles go a long way here. Breathtaking 360

Was probably not a good time to try the Kamikaze. The part up to Teneriffe Falls was fine but it got icy around 0.2 miles into Kamikaze, then thicker 2-3 inches snow around the upper part. It was also hard to see the path, we got off trail just about 7749 times, recommend downloading the map. We had to turn around close to the top because the trail wasn't visible anymore. Definitely need microspikes, if not have fun sliding like we did hehe. Oh waterfall was waterfalling though
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/mount-teneriffe-via-kamikaze-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Mount Teneriffe via Kamikaze Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":3},"reviewBody":"Was probably not a good time to try the Kamikaze. The part up to Teneriffe Falls was fine but it got icy around 0.2 miles into Kamikaze, then thicker 2-3 inches snow around the upper part. It was also hard to see the path, we got off trail just about 7749 times, recommend downloading the map. We had to turn around close to the top because the trail wasn't visible anymore. Definitely need microspikes, if not have fun sliding like we did hehe. Oh waterfall was waterfalling though","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Tram Nguyen","url":"/members/tram-nguyen-220"}}

reviews.text: Steep, can be wet and slick. Nothing crazy tho. No snowshoes required.
Great conditions right now, a little bit of snow on the peak but otherwise clear. Amazing view. recommend being in decent shape, from the waterfall on there's pretty much no rest, it just goes up.

Decided to take my little brother on a hike and this was a perfect trail for him. Super simple but rewarding at the end. We hung up hammocks and had a fun time. Parking lot isn’t huge but it’s not crowded so it was easy to get a spot. No bathrooms next to trail but there are bathrooms not far. I’d recommend downloading the map because it’s unclear at times which trail to take. 

Would definitely do it again!

3 stars for the view, minus 2 stars for the trail conditions and lack of bathrooms. Trail is not marked. There are multiple forks off this trail that clearly lead somewhere but there is nothing that tells you which way to go for the balcony so I would recommend a GPS. The trail is NOT well kept. For half of it, it feels like you’re just traipsing through the forest. It’s extremely overgrown which makes the complete lack of markings even more frustrating. There are NO bathrooms at the trailhead!!

The trailhead is hard to spot. Download a offline map since the trail is not marked! Small parking lot but since it was a rainy day we were the only car in the lot on a Sunday @9am. Northwest forest parking pass is required. Very rocky trail, some down trees and parts of the trail became a stream and was very slippery. Bring waterproof shoes, a waterproof jacket and trekking poles. Beautiful view at the top and the fall colors made the journey so much better.
I would vote this more of an easy trail! Definitely a good short hike
Very muddy. Only saw 4 other people on the trail. Started just before 3pm on Saturday. Back just after 4:30pm.

The hike was great today! It seems to have rained recently, so the river is going strong and lots of lush moss is growing on the trail, and some fun fungi. It’s nice to see the yellow deciduous trees down below in the valley in the fall season. Even got some sunbathing in at the top!

The trail itself is well-maintained with only a couple fallen trees that are easy to go around, but the potholes in the last hundred yards of the forest road were very deep and large, littering the ground like Swis
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/garfield-ledges--2","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Garfield Ledges","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"The hike was great today! It seems to have rained recently, so the river is going strong and lots of lush moss is growing on the trail, and some fun fungi. It’s nice to see the yellow deciduous trees down below in the valley in the fall season. Even got some sunbathing in at the top!\n\nThe trail itself is well-maintained with only a couple fallen trees that are easy to go around, but the potholes in the last hundred yards of the forest road were very deep and large, littering the ground like Swiss cheese… but our sedan made it with no major issues, so just drive with caution once you get to the last bridge.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Julia Gong","url":"/members/julia-gong-2"}}

reviews.text: Tons of potholes at the end of the road by the trailhead. Beautiful hike with great views of the mountains. Tons of mossy trees, mud, and some stairs along the hike.
Beautiful views!!
Awesome view with quick elevation
Beautiful day on the trail. Trail in great condition.    A few potholes in the parking lot.

name: Teneriffe Falls via Mount Si Trailhead

reviews.text: After mt tenneriffe Falls trail to the right, i Missed the sharp right turn up the slope- went by the branches and debis locking the old logging road Mt Teneriffe Trail until it metered out into an overgrown remnant trail that, mercifully,  at least, hooked up to the talus of shatp rock subdtrate i vowed never to hike up Mt Teneriffe Falls trail that, to my surprise. Led up and up to a beautiful fall. Glad I did it but came down the Mt. Tenneriff co.nevtor trail to Mt si trailhead.

Great loop. I've done quite a few different loops around Mt Si and Mt Teneriffe, and this might be my second favorite (behind one that goes Teneriffe Falls > Kamikaze > Mt Teneriffe > Mt Si - quite a bit longer). The Talus Loop and Roaring Creek trails are under-rated, so including both in one loop was fun. My only complaint is the loop doesn't include Mt Si, I'd consider going up there first next time and then coming over via the Connector trail. Anyway - good conditions, good scenery, bunch of

Trail was a little wet but overall in good condition. We did this as an out and back rather than a loop to avoid the rockier (and more crowded) part of the trail. Hardly anyone from the split off from the Mt. Si trail until we got to the falls. Mt. Si TH lot was full when we arrived around 11am - we’re lucky to get the last legal street spit.

Great trail to beat some of the Teneriffe G
Falls/Trailhead foot traffic and add a little more milage/elevation.
And Great for skipping the rockiest part of the Falls trail if you double back they way u went up instead of doing the loop.

Raining lightly lower and snowing lightly higher. Trail was good for the whole trip, no snow on the trail.  Not much for views because of weather. Teneriffe Falls was nice but we didn't stay long because we were pretty cold and wet by that point. Round trip took about 3:45hr.

Steeper and shorter ascent with a slightly more gradual, if somewhat meandering, descent.  Passed maybe 20 groups along the entire trail, but I did start late and the Old Mt. Si Trail is notably less popular (though very pretty and fun!).

The "Old" Mt. Si trail was in as good a shape as the New Si despite recent flooding, though there is generally more mud on the New Si trail due to design and higher use.

Definitely overpacked for safety since I didn't know exactly what I was getting into and

So, this particular trail has you going up the Old Si trail and down the new (and a couple other trails to end up back at the Little Si Parking lot. 

I would not do it that way again - I would take the New Si trail from that parking lot. Some of the sections on old si are just so steep it really is a tough ascent up. 

The views were great from the top - I didn’t have the time and energy to climb all the way at the end to the top of Mt Si but maybe another day taking the new trail. 

But for a

Very challenging but nothing that made me need to stop for too long, most of my non moving time was due to taking photos but definitely don’t underestimate the old si trail it forsure is a struggle at times and going down the new si made me so grateful because imaging going down again was very unpleasant lol. I made it to the beginning of the scramble but decided to turn back due to not having the right footwear and the wind was pretty intense. Overall it was a fun and challenging experience and
Not bad! Plenty of flats to catch your breath.
Parking can be difficult, trail is busy but large enough where it never feels congested.

12/31 - took the icy road to the upper trailhead and used all tools at my land rover’s disposal to get up and down in one piece. Chains would have helped. The lower trailhead should be fine but adds mileage.

Snow throughout the hike and deep beyond 3300ft where I used snow shoes and broke trail to 4800ft where I turned around upon sight of Rainier. Four avalanche chutes to cross with evidence of ~week-old slides. Poles and gaiters were essential and I used crampons on the way down.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/mcclellan-butte-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"McClellan Butte Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":4},"reviewBody":"12/31 - took the icy road to the upper trailhead and used all tools at my land rover’s disposal to get up and down in one piece. Chains would have helped. The lower trailhead should be fine but adds mileage.\n\nSnow throughout the hike and deep beyond 3300ft where I used snow shoes and broke trail to 4800ft where I turned around upon sight of Rainier. Four avalanche chutes to cross with evidence of ~week-old slides. Poles and gaiters were essential and I used crampons on the way down.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Will Gulliver","url":"/members/will-gulliver-1"}}

reviews.text: Trail was in mostly great shape but much wetter than expected with snowmelt and mist dripping from the trees the whole way up. Snow the last few miles but only about an inch max. Didn’t need micro-spikes. Only went a little ways up the scramble, a bit too treacherous for my experience level. Snowing on the way down. Highlight was being the first boot track up and following a bobcat’s tracks the whole way. Socked in, no views. Still was rad

Fairly moderate for the first 2/3 up. It gets a little tough the last 1/3 but the views are definitely worth it! Snowy for the last 1/3 up but nothing that couldn’t be managed. I suggest bringing extra layers as it does get much colder towards the top. Thankfully I always pack more than what I really need. The sun was out today so it made some of the snow melt making it slushy snow but as you got higher the snow was more compact. Micro spikes weren’t needed but they helped get some traction. Tra
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/mcclellan-butte-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"McClellan Butte Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Fairly moderate for the first 2/3 up. It gets a little tough the last 1/3 but the views are definitely worth it! Snowy for the last 1/3 up but nothing that couldn’t be managed. I suggest bringing extra layers as it does get much colder towards the top. Thankfully I always pack more than what I really need. The sun was out today so it made some of the snow melt making it slushy snow but as you got higher the snow was more compact. Micro spikes weren’t needed but they helped get some traction. Trail was in great condition. Overall great hike!","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Josh W","url":"/members/josh-waseta"}}

reviews.text:
Parking lot is closed so you’ll either have to park at a lot across the highway or along the street. 

Hike overall was a lot of fun. Spikes are a must. I managed without hiking poles. The short scramble to the top was completely dry as of today 2/4. Unreal views out to Rainier. 

Also clocked in a little over 12 miles, not the 10 shown.
Spikes required. Summit block became slippery as it was snowing hard on me (Feb 1st) but scramble was doable.

name: Grand Prospect via Rattlesnake Mountain Trail

reviews.text:
Very pretty forest walk! Great well maintained trail with a super gentle incline. PERFECT for running, up and down.

Took our two pups and had a ton of fun in the mist and rain. Couldn’t see anything at the top and went over to west peak to also see nothing but mist. Was super quiet and empty outside of a group of trail runners! We came back super drenched as it rained all hike long, with decently strong wind lol. Big parking lot (40 cars), and this trail is hikers only/dogs.

Highly recommend a

Use the parking lot at Snoqualmie Point Trailhead, not Snoqualmie Point Park. Take the bike/hike trail for 0.1 mile to the hiker only trail. Parking for about 40 cars. Only 10 cars at 9AM on a Tuesday. Bathroom x 2 (stocked).  Some freeway noise first mile. Well graded with less rocky stretches after first 2 miles. Crosses bike trails a few times. Would skip Stan’s Overlook as very overgrown with minimal view. Grand Prospect has nice view and 2 benches. Need to watch closely for “trail” from Rat
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/washington/grand-prospect-via-rattlesnake-mountain-trail","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Grand Prospect via Rattlesnake Mountain Trail","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"North Bend, Washington, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Use the parking lot at Snoqualmie Point Trailhead, not Snoqualmie Point Park. Take the bike/hike trail for 0.1 mile to the hiker only trail. Parking for about 40 cars. Only 10 cars at 9AM on a Tuesday. Bathroom x 2 (stocked).  Some freeway noise first mile. Well graded with less rocky stretches after first 2 miles. Crosses bike trails a few times. Would skip Stan’s Overlook as very overgrown with minimal view. Grand Prospect has nice view and 2 benches. Need to watch closely for “trail” from Rattlesnake Mountain Trail to the road to West Peak. Recommend downloading All Trails map so you do not miss it. Just a road walk to the peak through some regrowth after clear cutting.  At the top there is a fenced off communications station. There are good views in all directions by walking around a bit. Better than Rattlesnake Ledge. Too hazy to see Rainier today, but good views of Tiger, Mt.Si and Teneriffe, Mailbox to Bandera, Mt. Washington and McClellan Butte.  Exposed to sun on the road and peak.   \nOnly saw 6 groups on trail. Minimal bugs, no bites.\nMight be better to take Raging River Bike trail over to intersection with road south sotheast of peak and stay on road leaving peak north and east to minimize road time and maximize views.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"William Ehni","url":"/members/william-ehni-1"}}

reviews.text: Nice night hike and view over the north bend lights
Well maintained. Great for trail running. Not very crowded.

Trail was VERY well maintained. I recommend bringing a jacket as the entire trail is shaded. I did not realize there would be a designated trail for hikers and another for bikers. Definitely bringing my mtb next time :)

name: Iron Horse Trail: Homestead Valley Trailhead to Mine Creek

reviews.text: Nothing special…just a walk through the woods. Trail was nice and well maintained.
Very well kept trail and great views! You can hear i90 for a lot of the trail but it’s not too loud.

Great views! And super steady trail. To get from parking to the main trail there is a very steep start, but it only last an 0.2 mi. After that it’s flat all the way! 
Discovery pass is required. Dry but expect mid-high wind during winter months
Very easy for visitors or just a nice stroll. Did iron horse and lots of bridges and PNW views.
Beautiful little stroll. Really pretty old bridges and good views. This is a great trail for dogs, kids, and visiting family members. Not hard at all, but Beautiful.
